title: Happy with the product
text:
Happy with the product.

I was under the impression the metal filter with the ring, and the pressure relief valve cap replacement was a single unit, however they're separate. Not a big deal as the design is easy to clean.

My only complaint is that the cap is extremely tight on my aeropresses (2). Removing the cap after use is sometimes annoying as it the aeropress gets rather hot, and having to grip it tightly to remove the cap is annoying. Generally I run it under water on the sink, but this is introducing thermal shock and may contribute to decrease lifespan of the aeropress plastic.

title: The (second) best purchase I made in 2019
text: Last year, (whoop, two years ago now what?) when the weather started fluctuating, I started to get worried about my instruments' humidification.  Not unreasonably it seems as, once i got a decent digital hygrometer into my house, i was horrified with the results.  I actually bought two:  One analog and one digital.  I spent about 30 bucks for the privilege.  On a whim, i decided to buy these little guys for my instrument cases.  I didn't think they would be very good, but I have been wrong.  They nearly match my more expensive digital hygrometer and they are much more responsive than the more expensive analog one.. I put a few in some cases of pricier instruments and have peppered the rest in all the rooms of my house.  They are consistently precise when i put them in the same room, for example, and I have found them to have very good accuracy.  The batteries are button batteries and wear out fairly quickly but I have found them cheap to replace.  If I had it to do again, I might have just bought these and skipped the 30 dollar trip to the hardware store.  I really had no idea how dry it really gets in the winter shadow of my house until i looked.  Glad I looked when i did.  Honestly, I had no idea that humidification during that time would help me personally as much as it did.  I expected my instruments to be okay, but that was also the first year i didn't get sick for a month since i've lived in this house.  I couldn't have guessed how much the air quality would affect me.  Nice tools to have carried into the year 2020 where air quality seemed to be one of those things that people were suddenly thinking about.

title: Consider using the bleached variety for a cost savings. Both types make excellent brews.
text: Minimal paper taste, though I've read that the bleached (white) version also lacks pronounced taste and they do cost less. Be sure and rinse the filters with hot brew water before charging them with dry coffee. I've even tasted the rinse water and detect little, if any, flavor from the paper. Some experts suggest that the rinse is not necessary with these, but it certainly doesn't hurt anything, isn't difficult to do, and insures that no off flavors are contributed to the final cup, so why the heck not rinse?

title: Pretty, Optional Pitcher
text:
Pros:

The pitcher is nicely shaped and does work for steaming as described-- by pointing the steam wand at the bottom of the pitcher.

Cons:

Kinda pricey understates it, no?
It's really a shortcut that, in the end, though stylish and handsome, is not necessary. Practice makes perfect. Items like this and steaming thermometers are aimed at new recruits in the coffee army who become frustrated during boot camp and finally want something that just works. Believe me, I understand, but immerse yourself in videos, online advice, and visit good coffee shops (no, not *$s!). Watch the baristas. Some shops offer classes. While it might seem silly to take a class in "milk chemistry" or such, it's not. You'll gain by watching, listening, and speaking with others trying to master the craft.

If you love the look of this pitcher, and I don't blame you if you do-- it's cool looking, for sure-- buy it. But if it's just that you're not having luck steaming milk with a new machine, keep working. Avoid gimmicks that promise you a no effort shortcut. In the end, you'll be a better barista if you just stick with it, get the advice and instruction you need, and finally (and you will) master producing creamy microfoam.

Cheers, mates.

title: Go Ahead and Buy the Real Thing. Good Tools are Worth It.
text:
Heavy stainless with a well-secured handle. The shape supports easy frothing, though I can't speak to the "...Latte Art..." aspect as my latte art, up until this point, anyway, fundamentally sucks. I pull a pretty good shot, though.

Anyway, I think it's worth it to get this over the less expensive, lighter, tack-welded versions. If you make coffee everyday, get decent, pleasant-to-use-and-handle tools. Makes the whole process that much more enjoyable.

title: Works fine now. Now I wonder though if I really ...
text:
Works. But it took a bit of work to get to that point.

It's not a precise match as it doesn't fit the shield/housing/whatever-it's-called. So, once I got everything apart I saw that I had to get a new housing--not this igniter's fault of course but my housing shield was completely burned through. Luckily I got one from the local Wolf parts place for a reasonable price (unlike their price for the igniter which was the opposite of reasonable). But this igniter would not go all the way into the new housing. I had to open tabs and do a bit of bending of the sheet metal on the housing to get the igniter in. Not a big deal, mind you. Especially for the price here. Works fine now.

Now I wonder though if I really even needed it. Maybe my entire problem was the burned out housing and all I had to do was replace it. For the information: What my broiler was doing was not igniting for a very long time, and then coming on with a mini-explosion from the gas buildup. Was sort of ok if I opened the door and stood out of the way, but with the door closed the explosion literally blew it open about 6-8 inches. Needless to say I stopped using the broiler. I was told, by a supposed expert, that this was caused by ta bad igniter.

I now suspect it was the burned out housing not directing the gas to the ignitor until a critical mass of gas was reached.

title: These are awesome filters for the best coffee maker ever
text:
These are awesome filters for the best coffee maker ever. They're the official Aeropress filters, and they work great. I've tried a few off-brand Aeropress filters, and they aren't as good as these ones. Plus, these are extremely economical, so there's not really a reason to try off-brand filters.

There are 350 in here, so they'll last for a year if you drink one cup of coffee a day. They stay fresh, and even after a year or so they make great coffee, so it doesn't hurt to really stock up. They're really compact, so they don't really take up much space at all in your cupboard. I got a filter holder with my Aeropress, and all 350 of them fit nicely in it.

If you're looking at this listing, you probably already love the Aeropress as much as I do, but if you don't have one, you really need to get one. It makes the most delicious coffee I've ever tasted, much better than any coffee shop Americano. The coffee out of this is so delicious that I always drink it black. Plus, my Aeropress has already lasted through about 500 of these filters, which is a ton of delicious coffee for a couple pieces of plastic and rubber.

title: Don't believe the company's guidelines for sifter sizes for a French Press!
text: I followed the guidelines provided by the company to try to buy the right size sifters for a French Press, but ALL the sifters' openings were way too small for the size grind that my coffee grinder says is right for a French Press. We used Kruve only once and when we saw that all the sizes were way too small to work, we wanted to return it. But we were told that they would not accept a return once the product had been opened and tried (even only once). How are you supposed to know if it works until you try it? Their attitude was pretty much, "It doesn't work for your size coffee grind? Tough luck." They are way off base in the size sifters they recommend for French Press. You will need the largest set of 3 that they sell. Every configuration they sell (except the two smallest sizes) is set up in such a way that you have to buy a lot of sifters even though you only need 2 because you only make your coffee one way--for us it's a French Press. So this thing is just sitting in a cabinet--$100 down the drain.

title: nice little pitcher
text: This great for what it is! It isn't a super fancy precision-spout latte art competition pitcher, it's a simple functional milk frothing pitcher, in a very small size. I got the extra-small (mini) size, almost impossible to find from most milk frothing pitcher makers, to make flat white, cappuccinos, and macchiatos - particularly flat whites, my daily drink. It's the perfect size to put 4 fl oz of milk in, reaches just to the bottom of the spout, and aerates/swirls nicely. Putting such a small amount of milk in a standard 12 fl oz pitcher makes it much harder to manage the milk properly, and I don't like wasting excess milk. The price is very inexpensive, it hasn't rusted or broken, isn't bent or malformed, and works great at letting me do basic "latte art" (ferns, hearts, etc.). Pay attention to the size, the "mini" is quite small compared to normal pitchers.

title: Love love love it! Clothes are cleaner than ever before, and NO SOAP!
text:
UPDATE A YEAR LATER:
We are still totally happy with the pureWash. For really soiled items, like the napkins and placemats we use daily, I sometimes do a pre-wash with a tiny bit of soap, but otherwise never use any at all! If we use stain stick on items like shirt collars, I might do a pre-wash as well, but without adding soap, just to get a little more wash time.

One time I noticed the clothes were not clean when I removed them from the washer, and then realized someone had unplugged the pureWash. So you can definitely tell the difference. Our washer has an "eco-cold" water setting that uses no hot water at all. Apparently, most washers' "cold" setting uses a little hot water to help dissolve the detergent. Anyway, the colder the water, the better it works. We couldn't be happier with it. I still don't understand why utility companies and appliance salespeople aren't pushing this item more forcefully.

ORIGINAL REVIEW:
We recently had to replace our washing machine, and our local store had brochures about this unit. I'm surprised they didn't even try to sell it to me - I was just intrigued by the brochure and asked them about it. They charged about 25% less than the lowest cost I've seen online. Even though I used to wash mostly with cold water, I wanted it anyway because of its other features. First, it's just a cool gadget. Second, did I say this before? NO SOAP! Third, I no longer need to use hot water at all, even on towels and cloth napkins and cleaning rags like I used to. If you do use hot water, this should be what they call a no-brainer purchase for you.

I predict this will be the next big thing in the home appliance industry, as long as the soap industry doesn't find a way to scuttle it. Between this and our new washer, which uses much less water than our old first-generation Neptune front loader, our water and electricity bills are definitely going to go down this year. Plus our clothes look cleaner than ever before. Whites actually look whiter, just like the old detergent ads used to say.

This item is definitely a winner!

title: Perfect replacement for our GE range.
text: When the element in our 16 year old GE range went out, I looked at a lot of replacement elements that vary widely in price. This one had the same shape as the old one, so I figured it was worth a try forthe price. It was easy to install (just watch the YouTube videos) and it works perfectly. If anything it may be a little faster to heat up than the old one, although that may have been age related. Remember that the temperature is regulated by a thermostat - not the element, so don't worry about temps changing in your oven. We have noticed no changes when baking, and we just used the self-cleaning function. The element did fine. It seems there is no reason to pay more when this works so well!

title: Great tasting water for a long time.
text: We've tried several brands of these, and have found the quality sometimes varies even within the same brand from time to time. I've been very happy with this brand because it takes out the chlorine from our tap water and makes the water taste great. Better yet, we used the first of the two for 13 months without noticing in degradation in the taste of the water. Finally changed it out just because we figured we should. The second one is also working great. It should be noted that this is a carbon filter. It is only good for improving taste (like removing chlorine). It's not going to do anything for removing impurities. You'll need a more expensive filter for that.

title: Classy way to make good coffee
text:
I decided to try these after reading a lot of reviews by plastic-ophobes and coffee lovers, but mostly I liked the idea of classing up my coffee making by using a cool looking piece of porcelain rather than a cheap plastic unit.
After using it for a while, I would say that's the best reason to purchase this.
I can't say that I notice any improvement to either my health or the taste of my coffee from using this, but it looks great and it's easy to clean.
I had a little trouble at first with the water taking overly long to drip through, but found that if I rolled the bottom of the filter a couple of times it worked fine. The first filters I used were some cheap off-brand, and I think that was the real problem. Since I've been using Melitta natural brown filters I don't think it's probably necessary to roll the bottom of the filter, but I've gotten used to doing it, and haven't tried it without.
It's a nice piece of porcelain, and a fun way to make coffee.

title: Excellent replacements
text:
These were a great fix for my gas range (dg68-00101b, not listed as compatible but it was). It's hard to believe that Samsung makes the OEM knobs so poorly, 4 of the 5 original knobs were cracked and 2 were unusable within a year.

These don't look exactly like the originals, but they fit sturdily and are a vast improvement on the fragile OEM Samsung parts. Cosmetically they are close but have some sink marks that someone might notice up close, however no one is looking at my appliances that closely.

Highly recommend.

title: Excellent product
text:
I use this in conjunction with a Chemex and a Bonavita Gooseneck kettle. It took me a while to find the right grind and pouring method (straight down the middle, nothing fancy!) but now that I have it my "great coffee" has gone about about 95%.

The other 5% is usually user error - like forgetting to adjust the grind for more or less coffee or creating too long or short a pour over time.

This is expensive but worth it. I'll probably use both products every day for years.

title: Tiny and cute, makes great coffee for one, with patience
text:
Shown is the glass dripper with the companion Kalita Carafe. An eleven ounce mug is shown for scale.

It's great for making one mug of coffee, but you have to be careful, slow, and patient. The carafe helps a lot because you can see by the markings exactly how much coffee is coming out.

I also have the matching metal dripper which is great for travel.

Drawbacks would be how easy it is to overflow the tiny paper filter all over and make a huge mess of wet coffee grinds, so there is no shortcut to standing there slowing pouring the hot water. Would be better for someone who likes it weak and would use less ground coffee.

title: Very small.  Not even big enough for one serving.
text:
These are MUCH smaller than I thought they would be. They don't even reach to the top of the "2-4 cup" glass Kalita dripper. (Which is also a lot smaller than I thought.) A whole inch shorter than the standard #4s. No way this is for 4 cups.

On the other hand, the paper is nice and thick. They are even and symmetrical.

title: Go natural, go Hario!
text: Fit perfectly into my Hario 02 ceramic pour-over unit. Natural brown paper, with a soft texture. Just fold the side with the stitching over and place into the funnel. Pre-wet with your boiling filtered water and you are ready to go. Captures all sediments left from a burr grinder. Honestly this and the funnel have combined to create some of the best tasting coffee I have ever made, puts all auto-drip coffeemakers to shame.

title: Looks better than it functions.
text:
It is well built, but there are some drawbacks.
Because of its thickness, your hand senses a temperature a few degrees cooler than the milk inside while steaming. So the milk could already be overheated when your hand senses it as "just right"

The funneling inward near the top makes achieving a vortex a bit awkward vs. a straight walled pitcher.

And it's expensive. If you think this will help you pour better (it might, but not drastically) you're better off getting a Rattleware pitcher, and just practicing your technique.

title: too loud for a city apartment
text:
I bought this elsewhere, but felt I had to at least post my experience. This is the LOUDEST washing machine I've ever heard. We bought this for our apartment, and our downstairs neighbors immediately complained about the noise. Part of it is vibration, part of it is just the constant noise factor--it's never quiet during its entire operation. If you're in the same boat, make sure your apartment has 3 feet of concrete below it before you attempt to use this thing.

Sad, because it's such a great concept.

title: odd-looking, but very functional
text:
It's great so far. It looks like some odd kind of birth control for a goat, but it works.

We've tried a million things for a good single cup of coffee, and so far this is the best. Our most recent attempt before this was the metal cone filter, and that had to be thoroughly washed after each use with soap and then soaked overnight each weekend so it wouldn't completely clog up. So far, this contraption doesn't need any real care except a quick rinse--no clogging.

title: Great budget choice for 12 oz milk-frothing pitcher
text:
This 12 oz pitcher was a little too small for my espresso machine. It's not that it doesn't work, but that I am not yet in tune with my machine's powerful steal wand. That is no failing of this little pitcher though.

The pitcher looks nice and has now survived several hand washings and polishings with a lint-free cloth. There is no rust or other defects that would lower my review. Essentially, this is a great choice for a budget-minded home barista with either a weak machine, or a lot of finesse. If that's the case, you should have room to stretch 8 oz of milk and to let the microfoam develop a bit.

So far, I have not washed it a bunch of times or used it much. If there are any changes or noticeable defects over time, I'll supplement this review.

title: Excellent budget-grade milk-frothing pitcher
text:
The pitcher just arrived. It's packaged in a box, wrapped in a plastic bag. This would only be a problem if the carrier mishandles it or, if like mine, Amazon included no stuffing or bubble wrap. (Mine arrived in good condition.)

The pitcher is clearly labelled on the inside and fits my thermometer just fine. The intended use is for making lattes and cappuccinos in the mornings. I bought this to replace an 8 oz. X-Chef pitcher which turns out to be too small for my espresso machine, which has a very powerful steam wand.

As usual, I washed both pitchers before using, towel-drying the outside, and letting it air dry. No rust, so far, and the stainless looks nice.

I will supplement this review after I've used it for a while, and will note any deterioration in the pitcher or if it has other failings.

Update: I've had this pitcher for several months now. There are no signs whatsoever of rust or any other defects. I use it daily, hand washing and air drying it after each use. It's perfect for steaming 8 oz of milk, with plenty of room for foam and it makes pouring easy.

title: Plenty accurate for filament monitoring.
text:
I bought 6 and they all read +-1 of each other after 24 hrs. in the same zip-lock bag. I put one in each of my filament bags and change the desiccant when it reads over 20% at 60¬∞f. I've found you can't maintain a low enough humidity to keep filament from taking on moisture above about 65¬∞f and 20% is a good cutoff for "getting too high". 19% (or lower) always yields good print results. Moisture symptoms start to be detected above20%.
I'm planning to get another 6 or so.
Several months have gone by and the batteries are still fine. No telling how old they were already when they arrived.

title: Cautiously optimistic
text: After purchasing new rollers, idler pulley, and belt, I noted the axel shaft on one of the rear rollers had grooves and gouges in it.  So I hopped back on Amazon and ordered this.  Make sure you order the correct one (front or rear) because of how the nut threads.  I was initially worried because this replacement part does not match the original (see photo).  It did, however, fix the problem...so I'm cautiously optimistic.  Hoping the slight difference in size doesn't cause problems down the road.  This was for my Maytag Epic Z dryer.

title: Problem solved.
text: Based on the symptoms of my dryer (high-pitched squealing noise) the forums suggested I replace the belt, rollers, and idler pulley.  This pack conveniently includes everything, including the triangular plastic clips.  I wish they threw an extra clip or two, as I snapped one during installation (used an old one in its place).  So keep that in mind!  I was also concerned about the new belt because there were clearly rough spots on it.  I used a knife to carefully even it out.  This was for my Maytag Epic Z dryer.

title: pretty disappointed
text: Pretty disappointed with this purchase.  Spent a lot of time reading reviews.  There are a lot of 3 star exhaust fans out there and this was one of the few that received 4+.  Was disappointed the moment it arrived.  Everything about it is chincy.  All 4 metal brackets were bent.  It was a breeze to bend them back by hand because the metal was so soft (mind you, these are supposed to be the "sturdy" brackets to mount the unit to your joist).  The internal fan unit was somehow installed crooked in the housing when I pulled it from the box?  It was like somebody sat on it, causing it to be pushed into the housing on a 45 degree angle...bending some of the internal parts.  Had to pull it out and rebend to get it to sit flush.  The instructions show 3 screws holding the motor to the fan...but there was only 1 screw.  And it's not as though they just forgot some other screws...there weren't even other holes for the other screws!  Despite all of these things, I still brought it up to the attic to install.  Once I began the electrical work, I just couldn't take it.  The box is SO tiny, it is impossible to fit all of your connections in there...even if you had a 12/2 and 12/3!  Needless to say, I returned it, spent the extra $95 for a Panasonic and couldn't be happier.  The second I pulled the Panasonic from the box, I knew it was money well-spent.  Solid, straight, oversized electrical box.  Unfortunately, this Air King model just didn't cut it.  Actually, it didn't even come close.

title: Best bang for your buck
text:
5 stars for the initial review. Longevity is important for appliances...so we'll see how she does over the next months/years. Overall, I'm extremely pleased with this hood. For $300, it is what it is. It's eye-candy. Looks incredible and makes a huge statement. But everything else about it is just kind of "chincy." Not disappointed, as you have to expect that at this price point. The buttons don't push down very easily/evenly, the wires are dangling loose in the inner fan (some of their 3M tape came loose), some of the baffles fit loosely thus creating a lopsided effect (a gentle bending corrected the situation) the supplied screws/anchors are a joke. But hey, it looks incredible, and it does it's job...suck's the hot air. And for that, I'm stoked to spend only $300 on this! I've posted pictures for you to see....again, it looks awesome. The packaging job was incredible. And it comes coated with a protective film that protects the stainless finish until the final reveal. It is a little hard to peel off the film on the chimney extension unit. The other reviews said it scratches very easily...so I installed the chimney unit first, then peeled off the coating. I had to use a razor blade to score it just below the sight-line on one of the chimney extensions for a "clean break." Was a little nervous removing it from the box because some of the protective film had its own scratches. I was worried those would transfer to the stainless steel. Thankfully, they did not. The noise is a non-issue. It's a fan people...it's going to make noise. On the highest setting, you need to raise your voice if you're standing directly by the hood trying to have a conversation. But the other settings did not require my wife and I to "raise our voices." It's fine. Yes, all of the other reviewers are correct: buy new ductwork. The supplied plastic ductwork is a joke. It really is "easy" to install in that all you have to do is hang the thing. Everything else is literally plug and play!

One more thought. We have a 30" stove and I naturally was going to buy the 30" hood. But right before my purchase, I started doing a little more research and many suggested to purchase a hood larger than your stove, to ensure it covers all of your burners. So at the last second, I opted for the 36" hood. SOOOOO glad I did. Not only does it look better on the wall, it efficiently "sucks" regardless of what is cooking on any of the 4 burners.

Buy it. It's worth it. Let's just see how long it lasts......I'm cautiously optimistic.

UPDATE 4/25/2013: After only our second time cleaning the stainless steel baffle filters, the screw/nut that holds the baffle together stripped, thus rendering it useless. Obviously, we were pretty disappointed. I sent an email to customer service asking what the next step of action should be. They responded that same day with a tracking number and I had a new baffle in 2 days with no cost. I've never experienced customer service like that. Really, just outstanding. I'm still worried that issues like this may arise again, but for the price-point, I have to expect that (one of the same screws on another baffle sits crooked in the baffle, causing it to align poorly). My wife and I still love this hood...and after this customer service interaction, we're only more pleased with the purchase!

The first generation used to sell for about the same, but I guess because of scarcity (they're no longer made), folks are jacking up the price.

title: a good reusable filter if you like your coffee robust
text:
I had purchased a previous metal filter for my Aeropress which I didn't care for. I think the holes were just too large. This one works well and the fit and finish is good.

Note that the holes in any product of this type are going to be larger than a paper filter. That does have an impact on the taste because it lets more fines through, which creates a more robust (and if you're not careful, more bitter) cup. I like my coffee strong rather than smooth. So this is a good fit for me. I found I had to increase my grind size one notch to get the taste in the same ballpark as the paper filter. I can tell the difference between this filter and the paper filter. But I don't have a clear preference. They're just slightly different.

title: Fabulous little machine!
text:
I LOVE, love, love my little washing machine. I can pick it up--even with water in it! It takes more time than a sinble tub and you do have a bit more labor, but the extractor (spinner) removes so much water that the clothes dry very quickly which makes up the time. If you use very little soap--1/2 ounce liquid detergent, I use a shot glass--you can get great results with a 8 - 10 minute wash and one rinse. I would do two rinses, but water pressure is low at this RV park and filling takes a while, but everything is coming out very clean and soft--it's detergent residue that makes fabric harsh. I have never, ever used fabric softener and rarely use bleach, but my clothes are clean, bright, and very soft. More detergent does not make for more clean. Pre-treat stains and go easy on the soap.

I am amazed at how much is washes and love its flexibility. I do dirty jeans and cashmere sweaters--spinning is fine, it's agitation that causes shrinkage. The wash tub doesn't have an agitator, but rather rotates alternately clockwise and counter-clockwise like a front loader, so wool is fine--just be sure the wash and rinse water are the same temperature. I hang the clothes in a small room with a space heater and they are dry in as little as two hours for lighter weight garments.

title: Skip this one, buy another or stick with the original filter.
text: This filter is abhorrent. I used it once and it worked fairly well, it still allowed the coffee through too slow making the coffee taste over brewed. Not the fresh clean taste you normally expect from a siphon. Every time after that the filter has only allowed half the coffee through before giving up and just refusing to brew. I honestly got far better tasting coffee from the original filter. I'm planning to try a few other reusable ones.

title: Great coffee brewer.
text: Where do I start. The aeropress is an amazing piece of equipment. Anyone who is looking for a really great cup of coffee, that tastes amazing and has a low impact on the environment then this is for you. You have the single serve convenience of a keurig, yet not all the wastefulness of the k-cups and all the packaging. Especially if you get yourself the "Able Brewing Disk" (do yourself a favor and buy them both at once). The idea of purchasing a manual coffee maker such as this may seem a little daunting, but after about a week of using it you won't even notice the slight bit of extra work you have to put into making your morning coffee. And trust me, the enhancement in flavor over anything you have brewed with in the past will blow you away, and make up for the little extra work you have to do. Not only is this a genius solution for making yourself a single cup of coffee with out wasting an entire pot, but it's a great solution for making a delicious iced coffee. Just brew it directly into a cup of ice, the heat from the brewing coffee will melt the ice and you will have a perfectly balanced cup of iced coffee. So if you want a great cup of coffee without leaving your house, this is the simplest solution.

title: The wisest choice I've made in awhile.
text: This is probably the best investment I or anyone could make. Since I found out about dioxin's (the agent they use to bleach coffee filters) affect on the GI tract I have been using unbleached filters. I thought this would be yet another step in the right direction. To use something reusable so as to lessen my impact on the environment, and also not pollute my body with necessary toxins. Stainless steel (which this is made of) is one of the least offensive (to your body) metals you can use. Most everything metal in my kitchen is Stainless steel, and I can rest easier knowing I'm not clogging my body with heavy metals. If you are concerned about your personal impact on the environment and making the best choices for you personal health, then this is the filter for you.

title: Not standard V60 filters
text:
Been getting Hario filters from Amazon for a couple of years. I thought these would be the same. They are not. They are taller and thicker and have a "tab" on one side which none of my other filters have had. After I few uses I noticed that my brew times were going long..by minutes, not seconds. At first I thought I had inadvertently moved my grinder. No. I looked more closely at the filters. I had noticed the "tab" right away but everything else on the packaging looked OK so I just assumed they were correct. Not so. I'm trying to use the rest of them in an immersion brewer I play with sometimes and I'll replace these for my pour over.
[[ASIN:B00GH5JTHW Hario 02 100 Count Coffee Paper Filter, White- Value Set of 2 Pack (Total 200 Sheets)]]
3/16/16 Update: I purchased from a second seller now and received the same product: "Flexible V60 Coffee Style" filters which are just not acceptable for the reasons above. The image on the product page is of the original package, not the "Flexible" filters I recieved. Returned them and I'll try again.

title: Accurate within a rather broad range
text: Easy to read the display, dual mounting options (mount or use integrated stand). Good for the price.  The only thing is that the temperature and humidity are only accurate within a rather broad range. I bought two of these, and while the temperature is within one degree of each other, the humidistat is 3 percentage points apart from each other. One of them agrees with an older, more expensive humidistat I already owned, and the other does not agree. If the humidity accuracy is not particularly important to you, this one is fine.  And as I say, one of the two is spot on.

title: An excellent dryer, without unnecessary bells & whistles
text:
After a bad experience with my "state of the art" Maytag computer-called-a-dryer, I opted for simplicity this time. One knob (replacement cost for whole timer assembly $90) and one start button (replacement cost $8). Nice, clean look, inside and out. Was at first disappointed that there is no interior light, until I realized I don't need it- the "mouth" is very large and it's easy to see all the way inside. The lint filter (on the top) is large and easy to use. Setup/hookup was simple and fast. This dryer is very quiet, and the heat control is excellent. I just dried several king sized sets of linens, following a very large load of bath towels, and the automatic setting on "eco" mode worked as well as it possibly could. Dry time was shorter than with the Maytag, and the items were cool to the touch when I got them out (the cool-down feature really works, and saves gas). With the Maytag, everything was always very hot when I removed them, telling me that the gas was on longer than it needed to be. This dyer is super-easy to use, holds very large loads (you'll never miss that other .5 cubit foot)is economical to buy and operate, and repair (if it ever needs it).

What you have to be willing to give up:
buzzer
LED telling you how much time is left
light inside the drum
1/2 cu. foot of interior space (compared to 7.0 dryers)

What you don't have to give up:
Quiet, efficient drying
reliability
simplicity- all controls are on one dial
multiple automatic drying cycles
three temperatures
timed drying options
a lot of cash- Extra knobs or buttons add $100+
name brand (like other identical models under different brand names, this is a Whirlpool)

title: Best Coffee Maker!

title: Love this filter
text: I am not a handy person at all and neither is my boyfriend, so it took us a while to figure out how to install it correctly. It was worth the hassle because my ice no longer smells or tastes funny. This filter was recommended by a friend and I am so glad I bought it! I have an old refrigerator (~2009) with an ice maker only in the bottom freezer drawer. The double sided tape that came with did not hold up very well. The next morning after the install the tape did not stick allowing the filter to fall to the floor. I ended up using gorilla tape and all is well now. Highly recommend this product!

title: Total Dissatisfaction
text:
This was one of the most disappointing purchases I have ever made. Very noisy. Ice is wet and not solid so it melts quickly watering down drinks. Made my husband a cocktail and within just a couple of minutes all the ice was melted.
Nice design and easy to use. Do not recommend.

title: Makes a good cuppa tea OR other strained beverage
text: I'm really happy with these unbleached filter papers. Oddly enough, I started using them in earnest over in Kauai. I simply COULD NOT find a teapot on that entire island - no kidding! They were not at Macys, Kmart, Walmart or Costco. I actually ended up buying a glass coffee pot to use as a teapot at the local Ace Hardware. Ack. Then it occurred to me to find and buy a teapot here at Amazon.com! However, that was comically WEEKS into my 2.5 mo stay. In the interim, we used these tea filters day after day, to make not only a pot of tea (in the coffee pot!), but also cups of tea in a mug. The paper imparts no obnoxious flavor to our tea, drapes easily enough over the side of a receptacle, and allows one to RINSE the tea leaves before steeping. Yes, that is the secret to a clean cuppa tea: rinse the leaves for a few seconds with boiling water (or under your tap's HOTTEST water). I now travel with these filter bags in case a teapot is hard to find. And believe me, they are becoming as rare as a unicorn over here in the U.S. More recently, I have been using these filters to make ginger-soothers. After surgery, if you are feeling queasy, just grate up fresh ginger root, place in this filter bag, and then let it steep with either water or sparkling water to your desired concentration. Works like a charm!

title: Buyer Beware
text: This product is advertised to make the first "batch" in 6-15 minutes.  My experience has defined a batch as 6-10 ice cubes.  Also note, this product is advertised to make "up to" 28 lbs of ice per day.  However, it stops making ice once the basket is full.  So if you would like any more than the 2 lbs of ice that it stores in its basket at a time, not makes at a time.  Either way, that would require someone to empty the basket every time it fills which is about two hours.  The only way to produce 28 lbs of ice per day would be emptying the basket round the clock.  The two pounds that it takes two hours to make is less than half of one bag of ice purchased from most stores.  If you're on the edge about purchasing this item, also take note that the seller will deduct their shipping cost from your refund in addition to you having to foot the bill to ship it back.  No, thank you!

title: I am pleasantly surprised
text: My last Keurig, purchased a few weeks ago, lasted for 1 day. It is inexplicably dead. I called Keurig and they said they wouId have it picked up and then check it over and then only would they send a replacement. However, they never followed through as I never received the mailing label as they promised. I was tempted to buy the Keurig commercial K-155 but that is quite a beast and I really could not see that in my humble kitchen. So, I searched for something that might be better and I came across this SS-10P1. I can't say that I am crazy about its design. There is a shiny chrome handle on top that gets immediately smeared with fingerprints and looks terrible. Also, the mechanism that operates the pod chamber just operates roughly and seems poorly designed. Having said all that, this brewer makes a very good cup of coffee for a pod machine. It seems to extract more flavor than Keurig and I think that is because it brews about 30 seconds longer than Keurig. I don't seem to have the problem with splattering some have reported. I'm sure that's because I tend to use relatively tall cups. I'm not a fan of the LCD panel with its garish blue light but to each his/her own. I don't bother with the clock and on and off times as the machine seems to use scant power while it is on. I believe the water heats on demand as there is no rumbling of boiling water from inside at any time. Also, I always use the 8oz cup size so I seldom have to puzzle over the tiny little cup icons to choose something else. I just let the machine stay on all day and I turn it off before retiring. The power switch is conveniently on the side. The hot water and rinse features are useful. Rinse always gives 4oz of hot water while the hot water option is variable by the cup size you select. The functions are similar, but different. I like the big tank. The machine is not unusually noisy but you will hear it. It sounds just like an aquarium pump if you are familiar with such things. It is just a humming sound that is subdued and certainly not louder than any Keurig machine I have heard. My final comment is that this machine is accompanied by a comprehensive instruction booklet. This is a nice touch and, to me, it shows the manufacturer has some interest in customer satisfaction. So I recommend this brewer. If you want the convenience of a pod brewer and wish to avoid the Keurig dice roll of longevity I would say get this Cuisanart.

title: Perfect replacement for Samsung filter in my refrigerator
text: I have been using these for about a year and have used 3 so far. I change them when my fridge complains that it's time to change the filter. They are excellent quality. The o-rings are greased and a cap covers the opening to keep things clean. I have no problems with water flow or taste. I just ordered another pack of 3 filters. I have nothing to complain about as these seem to be the same quality as the OEM Samsung filter which costs a lot, lot more.

title: Won't fit the angle plug of Samsung fridge
text: This seems to be a well-constructed device. However, the engineers did not put much thought into how the fridge would connect. They have recessed the socket. This makes it impossible to fit a wide plug into the protector. My Samsung plug is wide and just won't fit. If I try to use an outlet extender the added weight lets gravity pull the plug from the protector since the outlet is angled downward. All this is too bad since this otherwise seems to be a good product. I suppose I could get creative with cutting the case or using cable ties for support but there is a limit to my patience with something that should work out of the box.

title: My favorite filter for Cup-One
text: I tried to save a few pennies by using Melitta #2 filters. These worked well. However, after that box ran out and I went back to Technivorm, I was amazed at how much more flavorful my brewed coffee became. I never had any problem with either brand of filters coming apart or anything like that. The Melitta filters are just a bit thinner and have to be picked out of the basket after brewing. The Technivorm is thicker and just upending the filter basket over the bin will drop out the grounds and filter all as one. So, if you can afford the slight bump up in price over Melitta, I really recommend these filters.

title: No problems with these
text: These work exactly as one would expect. It's a quality filter for the Moccamaster.

title: No problems with these
text:
I have been using these for several years and I have noticed no difference in ‚Äútab‚Äù vs. ‚Äúno tab‚Äù.
My brew times have stayed the same. Perhaps those experiencing problems need to look to their grinders as the cause of the problem? I use a steel burr grinder which produces very little dust, known as ‚Äúfines.‚Äù Fines can clog the filter and slow down the brew. Maybe the newer filters are easier to clog with coffee fines? Anyway, I'm really at a loss to understand how others are having such terrible problems with these excellent filters.

title: Excellent
text: These work great. I have never had one open up or rip. Perhaps a little on the expensive side but the excellent cup of coffee is worth it.

title: Much better coffee than with paper filters
text: As much as I love the AeroPress brew, the flavor has always been a bit lacking. Having tried the Slimm filter I have solved that problem. The coffee is much more flavorful. I suppose the paper filters I had been using really did soak up some of the essential bits that make the flavor bloom. The only tradeoff is a tiny bit of sediment (very tiny) in the cup and one more piece to rinse clean. I'm not complaining, though. This filter seems well made and I suspect with reasonable care it will last a long time. Having received a second filter for free in the current (Dec 2015) promotion I can say this is a solid investment in brewing great coffee.

title: A bit too narrow at the top
text: This is a well-made pitcher of thick stainless steel. My only complaint is that it is too narrow at the top. If you try and use it with a thermometer you may find yourself cramped for space as I do. Also, when you swirl the milk while steaming, it tends to swish very close to the top of the pitcher even if you only fill it 1/4 full as I do. Small complaints though. A nice pitcher.

title: Excellent replacement filter
text:
So glad Amazon Basics offers this filter! It specs out better than the OEM I replaced it with - the OEM had a 200 gallon capacity, this one is 300 gallon capacity. It also meets NSF standards 42, 53, and 401 - this refers to the performance of filtration. This means that it is tested to reduce chlorine, cyst, lead, benzene, endrin, carbofuran, plus phenytoin, ibuprofen, naproxen, estrone, bisphenol A, and nonyl phenol. I don't know what many of those are, but they can't be good for you. And honestly, I've not tested my water and although our tap water tastes okay this added filter makew the water taste better, so it must be doing something right!

And you really can't beat the price. At about half the price of an OEM, I will be buying the premium version of this every six months. Just wish it was on Subscribe & Save so I can have one delivered every 6 months without having to think about it.

title: I just can't really say I'm crazy about these towels.
text:
These are a nice, rich dark green color but I can't quite get used to the feel of the microfiber. For one thing, if you have dry hands, these will sort of stick to them (not sure how to describe that feeling, hopefully those of you who have experienced that before understand). While they do dry things, the just don't seem as absorbent as a regular cotton towel. I think that may just be my perception because I haven't actually compared the absorbency - it just feels different when I'm drying my hands (again, difficult to explain). Perhaps it's just such a different feel from a cotton towel that I'm having trouble adjusting, I don't know.

I just can't really say I'm crazy about these towels. If I grow to love them, I'll modify this review, but for now they are average - just okay.

Maybe expectations were too high when I purchased this product and that may have been the difference between the 3 stars I gave these and the 4 they could have possibly earned.

title: Perfect Fit, Reliable, Strong, And Reasonably Priced
text:
My wife and I drink a ton of coffee. That may sound like an exaggeration but if you look back over our two lifetimes it turns out not to be a stretch. Typically we each have 4-5 cups per day, most of which are prepared in 10 cup coffee makers requiring a size 4 coffee filter.

We have stuck with Melitta Cones because they do a great job of filtering the coffee. No grounds make it through the filter and no additional taste is added to the coffee. These filters are strong enough to pick up by the top without collapsing and creating a mess.

Add to that the great Amazon pricing and the fact that they are delivered to our door. What more could you ask for?

title: Be Very Careful When Removing The Used Filter From The Coffee Maker
text:
These Melitta Cone Coffee Filters fit our KitchenAid coffee maker perfectly, the configuration of the filters allows the coffee to get full exposure to the water through it, and the price is right. The combination of a pour over coffee maker using a good blend with these filters results in a full-flavored cup of coffee without the acidic taste.

HOWEVER, I have found that if you let the grounds sit in the filter for any length of time, that the filter will tear at the corner when you lift it out, resulting in coffee grounds going just about everywhere. That gives you an unexpected bit of extra work and is not an easy mess to clean up. Melitta states that these filters are "double crimped" for extra strength and "guaranteed not to burst". I guess that 'bursting' is not the same as 'tearing'.

title: I Can't Find Anything Bad To Say About It

This is a simple tool that does it's job well. I wanted a vertical unit for the small footprint and the gray color. It holds 30 K-Cups securely (even when spinning it on its revolving base) and it's easy to pull one out without displacing any of the others.

Light weight, attractive, and reasonably priced. You couldn't ask for more with this unit.

title: It worked! I have 9 baby chicks!
text: At first I was skeptical because it doesn't regulate humidity except for saying to add this much water this week, add more water this week, and so on. But the temperature held steady throughout.  When hatch day arrived, the eggs started hatching but continued for 4 more days. Not sure if that's the norm or maybe the temp or humidity was off a little.  But I eventually got 9 out of 9 eggs hatched.  Perfect for a beginner like me who doesn't want to spend a fortune on an incubator that I won't be using often.  I think if I was going to do this more often, I'd invest in a bigger one. My eggs are average size and I could only fit 9.  If I put more in, it wouldn't have been able to turn them properly. All in all, good starter incubator. It worked for me.

title: So Far, So Good..
text:
Bought this Pro 30" Range over at ABT in Illinois. I've had it installed for a good month now and loving it.. My primary use is the range and happy with the output of each of the burners.. I haven't tried using the oven and likely won't until turkey day.

It looks beautiful and compliments our fully remodeled kitchen with other Frigidaire Professional appliances. One thing I'm impressed with is the surprising ease of keeping the stovetop clean.. I primarily cook with coconut oil and so far all the grease and food residue has wiped cleaned w/o issue.. I was fearing I'd have a charred surface in no time but being how easy it's been to clean I reckon it will retain it's lustrous stainless steel surface for quite some time to come. One thing to note is the depth of this as ours protrudes a good inch from the counter. The inch I'm speaking of is not of the stainless frame but of the actual sides‚Ä¶The ‚Äòblack interior' sides . Not a huge deal breaker but when you pay $38k for a kitchen remodel, you want everything to be perfect! Our contractor knew what slide-in range we had selected so perhaps it just wasn't possible to get an exact fit.

As far as ordering with ABT goes, it was excellent. We reside in Southern California and no local store, independent or chain could compete with ABT's pricing.. That coupled with paying No Tax (sorry CA gov!) made them the clear winner.. It took about a week to get here and the driver would only deliver to our garage.. We didn't pay for white glove so no issue there. Oh, and huge props to the customer service. The range went on sale within 7 days of us ordering it and after speaking with an agent, they refunded the difference..

text:
The ItsNio Stove Covers which are for a Samsung Gas Range were too long for my Whirlpool range since they were extra-long, but at 32 inches wide they were an excellent fit. Since I've been having pretty good luck with items for a Samsung gas stove fitting my range, I took a chance and ordered them.
With a bit of trimming they fit my stove easily and so far they have helped keep my stove top cleaner since they are non-stick and washable.

The Bottom Line: If you own a Samsung gas range then I have no doubt the ItsNio Stove Covers will be a perfect fit and for $25.90 they are worth the price to keep the top of a gas range clean.

title: Worked well for my Whirlpool stove
text:
LONGADS item number DG64-00473B Replacement Stainless Steel Gas Stove Knob, Compatible with Samsung Gas Range, is a perfect fit for my Whirlpool WFG550S0HZ1 gas range. I wasn't sure it would fit,- but I took a chance since this knob had similar backs to my original plastic ones, which melted the first time I used my oven. This knob from LONGADS is sturdy and held up well over the thanksgiving weekend when my oven was working overtime.

The Bottom Line: $38.99 may seem expensive for one stove knob, but one OEM replacement was more per knob than the price of the LONGADS range knob. Additionally, the Whirlpool OEM knobs are not steel core, nor would I replace the OEM knobs again because I have no doubt they would melt again, which makes the LONGADS DG64-00473B Replacement Stainless Steel Gas Stove Knob a value in my book.

title: Better than the cheap plastic one that came with my stove
text:
The Bioduck [Upgraded] DG64-00473B Samsung Stove Knobs (2Pcs,) fit my stove perfectly even though it is a Whirlpool and not a Samsung. The first time I used my oven, the knobs that came with it warped and melted, and the center one of five broke. Replacement knobs, which would have been plastic again, were ridiculously expensive; then these Bioduck replacement knobs came to my attention. They looked nice, thankfully, weren't plastic, and if they didn't match, I could return them. Happily, they not only fit, but they look better than the originals.

The Bottom Line: Even though these seem pricey at $69.99, Bioduck's Replacement Knobs are nowhere near as expensive as the OEM knobs and are far better quality.

My body finally rebelled and I had to reluctantly use the local laundromat. $6.25 per load for the jumbo washer that holds 3 regular washer loads. The amount of residual soap that came out of my hand washed clothing was shocking. I thought I'd been doing pretty good but I wasn't. So, I bought a portable washing machine from Amazon. The Helohome Portable Washer. What a blessing! My clothes have never been cleaner and my body is no longer in so much pain. So, save the breathing mobile washer for when there's no other way to do laundry and store some Depends so you always have clean underwear during a crisis.

title: Works great!
text:
Works great! Unlike most other refillable cups, the Eco-Carafe lid is thin enough to allow the top of the brewer to close.

The Eco-Carafe makes nice coffee albeit a little weak. The problem is the Keurig 2.0 brew temperature is very low. I am on my third replacement K560 for that reason. Keurig states the brew temperature is 192 degrees for k-cups and 197 for k-carafes, but all three Keurig k560,s have water temperature of 172-174 degrees at the dispensing needle.

If you use a fine to medium grind, it will still make a good carafe of coffee. It also helps to select "Bold" when you brew!

Perfect Pod said they will have paper filters to fit the Eco-Carafe. This will help to slow down the brew. Until then I'm making my own filters.

I have a large mug, and I like to brew 16 ounces at a time. The Eco-Carafe allows me to use enough grind for a nice mug of coffee.

Oh, it's the color that allows this to work in the Keurig 2.0

I highly recommend the Eco-Carafe!

Just make sure you do not over fill these.

The lids and filters also work with used k-cups. Remove the foil cover and then clean up the original paper filter or carefully remove it and use a new Simple Cup filter. The lids are tight so you must use the jig. If you don't use the jig, you will just crush the cups.

In just a few minutes I had 5 or 6 of these cups ready to go.

After use, pop off the lid, toss the used filter and use it again and again.

title: Disappointing at best.
text:
Part of the reason for our Keurig purchase was this item. We could get the reusable filter and not have to go through the waste of the k-cups. Sadly, this makes a sub-par cup of coffee. Not only is it tedious, you have to go through all kinds of extra steps that aren't part of the manufacturer's intended instructions to get it to make a decent cup of coffee. Most coffee comes out weak unless you put a used k-cup at the bottom of the thing before putting in the filter to slow the flow of the water. Plus, you gave to pack in a LOT of coffee to get a reasonable cup of coffee. Then, so it doesn't overflow and put grounds in your cup, I use a toothpick to kind of bore out the center so the water can flow in a little better. You can stop the leakage for the most part by putting a rubber band around the very top where the lid screws on, but if I'm paying as much as $20 for this, then I'd like it to work without my having to put in so much effort. I've also read several reviews about how quickly these break, and while mine has not yet broken, I can see where it will. Very shoddy construction. It's a disappointment.

To sum it up, you CAN get a good cup of coffee out of this, but it's going to take work and practice to figure it out. Nothing like just plopping in a new k-cup and closing the cover and pushing the button...

text:
Buyer Beware!

Purchased this range hood in January 2014, it worked fine for about a year and looked good (although there's no way it's really working at 900CFM, btw). It suddenly began malfunctioning -- randomly changing fan speeds, refusing to turn off or on, lights turning off and on randomly. I had to start controlling it at the breaker box, which is very inconvenient since my overhead kitchen lights are on the same circuit. After about a month, it stopped working at all even when the breaker is on. At least I can use my overhead lights now!

It's still under the 3 year parts warranty and I've sent 2 emails to the manufacturer, Golden Vantage, and haven't received any response.I'll update if I hear from them.

title: Love this ice maker!
text:
We used to have one of the bullet ice makers and it worked great for our family of 4 for over 2 years, but it finally died and we wanted to replace it with one that provides even more ice so we never have to wait for a batch to get done. This ice maker is amazing and makes so much ice that we never run out! It is true that the ice comes out looking like a candy bar in full sheets, so to deal with that I bought a double walled ice bucket with lid for the countertop. It has a stainless tong and a scoop so I use the tongs to pull the ice sheets out of the ice maker, put them in the bucket, then use the scoop to break them up. It's easy and lets the ice maker continue to make ice while we use up what is in the bucket.

Just one warning: the top filling feature was a little bit of a pain for me with how my kitchen is set up because you can't fill it easily if the ice maker is under top cabinets. I had to rearrange things on my countertop so I could put the ice maker where there are no top cabinets and it's perfect placement now. If you have top cabinets all around your kitchen with very few open areas, it might pose an issue for you when it comes to filling the machine and would be very inconvenient.

I can't review based on longevity because at this point I have only had this ice maker for a month. But what a great month it is has been!

Pros:

Clear ice
it's a workhorse and makes a ton of ice every day
It's a good looking machine
Easy to clean (instructions in manual)
Pretty quiet when it's running (see caveat below)

Cons:

Big ice blocks come out so you have to have a system in place to break them up
Cannot fill easily under top cabinets
Takes up more counter space than a bullet ice maker
Can be a little loud when the ice falls into the basket (it startles my dog if he's in the kitchen and it's hilarious)

This ice maker is working beyond my expectations and I am thrilled with my purchase. I highly recommend it for people who love ice to the brim of every drink!

title: Ah, the glamorous life I lead
text: It's definitely not the raciest or interesting product, but it sure comes in handy when your dryer lint has gotten out of hand and you need to deal with it! My electric bills have been off the wall and my house very dusty and dry. I have 2 kids and 6 pets so I do laundry all the time, literally every single day. I was completely boggled by the higher electric bills since I have been changing all my lightbulbs to LEDs, bought new more efficient appliances, etc. until the power co installed a smart meter that allows me to go online and look at when energy is most used. I realized from the charts they provide that my dryer was going bonkers, drawing so much energy, and since I do laundry every single day, it was making a muck out of my electric bill. We detached the back dryer hose and piles of fluff came out. We started cleaning the aluminum duct only to realize that it was so full of junk, we decided to just replace it. But that left the pipe leading up and out of the house to deal with. To help with the long pipe, I bought this magnificent lint remover. We didn't even use a drill because it is so tight behind my dryer so it is hard to maneuver, but even using it by hand, tons of stuff came out anyway. Unfortunately we have to have a wire cage over our vent that leads outdoors or birds get in and we will need to get out on the roof to get the lint off that. We will clear that out and then run this brush through to the inside to make sure we got everything. Lesson learned to check on the dryer vent more often and head issues like this off before they start. Without this tool there is no way we would have been able to get all the lint out of the pipe as it has two elbows running out of the house. It gives me peace of mind that we are starting again with a cleaned duct system and we know now to schedule in regular maintenance. When I was growing up, I never remembered my parents cleaning the back of the dryer (though they probably did I guess and I missed it) so it didn't occur to me that it could be such a problem in just a few short years. I am so glad that modern technology alerted me to a potential hazard in my home and that this product was available for purchase to help deal with it.

I wanted a no-frills machine that would give me another 20 years of service that was manufactured in the USA, and this one fit the bill. title: Oven just does not work
text:
We have had this range since August 2013, and in the less than 2 years we have owned it, we have had 5-6 service calls on it. The cooktop has failed on us once (one side stopped working), but the oven is the real headache. It intermittently just decides to shut off and flashes "Feature not available" when you try to turn it back on. This happens in all modes - regular and convection. It sometimes gets fixed by resetting the circuit breaker that it is plugged into, but that only works about 30% of the time. Sometimes letting the oven cool off completely and then retrying works, but not consistently. I have had it fail in preheat mode and while baking (not a good thing to come back to check on a cake and discover the oven is off).

We had the motherboard replaced twice within the first year of use. The oven just went out on me again tonight, and I am ready to heave it out of my kitchen and into the backyard. I love cooking with this stove when it works, but it just doesn't stay working. It actually went out on me on Thanksgiving morning, and I almost had to cancel dinner... Thank goodness we got it working after an hour of trying circuit breaker resets and letting the oven cool off. I am just so frustrated.

title: Not my first Comfee', but so far the best
text:
We had a smaller Comfee' washing machine (.9 cub.ft) that worked great for 2 years. Then the little guy sprung a leak, it was out of warranty, and we decided to donate it and buy a bigger machine. This one IS bigger, fits a lot more. I have done about 6 loads so far, and if things change I will update the review. This time I bought an extended warranty for it, so it will be going back if something goes wrong.

It is louder than my last one, you can hear the motor rev up when it does the spin cycles. In general this is better, it revs up‚Ä¶in increments, helping the load to balance in the bin before hitting top speed. Love this, versus my old machine that I would refill (a waste water) when it was out of balance to re-distribute the clothes. It does mean the motor can get a little loud when it does this, but not so much that you worry about neighbors hearing it or can't have a phone conversation in front of it. Just enough for me to notice it was more than my last .9 cubic ft machine.

One other thing, if you set it for 1 spin cycle - that doesn't seem to include a full rinse (I expect it to fill the bin, move clothes around in fresh water, extract water and then spin). It seems to trickle water over the clothes as the bin moves around a few times and then it spins at high speed to do the final cycle. Sort of confusing, and I am still learning to see if there is another pre-set program that works differently, but I find choosing (2) spin cycles solves this issue. I expect a rinse cycle to do more, I guess!

Otherwise it's pretty good. I can do larger loads, with room so the clothes can move around and get clean. Will update if anything changes as I keep the machine longer.

title: Great washer, saving me from visiting the local laundromat
text:
I have a small cabin in the mountains that did not have connections for a large washer/dryer...so I bought this smaller machine and dryer to save me from having to go out to the laundromat. Especially when we get a couple of feet of snow...doing laundry at home is so much better. It fits everything nicely, even large 'thick' towels. I have also done CalKing sheets in it too, full set w/ pillowcases at the same time.

I notice the machine can get out of balance with heaver/larger items, so sometimes I need to split those up, but in general it works out very well. No leaking (I have had it about 4 months so far), if it gets out of balance the machine automatically adjusts itself and sometimes I don't need to do anything at all. I find it re-balances the load better than I can - it is pretty smart - which surprised me the first time it did that!

It's a keeper and a lifesaver! My one gripe is I should have bought the slightly larger version of this machine - I might have been able to get my quilts done in it. Right now, I will have to still go to the laundromat a few times a year to get larger stuff like that washed.

title: Where has this little machine been?
text:
First review (after quite a few uses): okay, I got lazy, laundry was taking over a corner of my room because I just could NOT go to the laundry mat one more time. I bought a portable washer & this dryer and was so thrilled they both came within a day of each other. And now I am dancing through the house exclaiming "Where have you been for the past 3 years??". I should have done this much sooner when I first looked these machines up on Amazon. I live in a small cabin that does not have a washer/dryer hookup and it has been a nightmare going to the laundry mat in town.

This dryer has been wonderful, and it is plowing through the laundry that has built up with ease. Super simple to use, lots of options depending on what you are drying, quiet and venting out the back door is convenient. I bought a larger dryer than the washing machine because I wanted to make sure everything could tumble around and dry without wrinkles or wet spots. So far it is great! I know once I get through the bags of laundry, and to a normal schedule of only a load a week, it will be sent from heaven as far as I am concerned. No standing at the laundry mat, no icky stuff coming out of the machines, no icky people (yeah, even the super small rural area I live in has those).

title: You Tube will walk you through the entire job
text: My Dryer quit heating... Googled my Dryer model & found a YT video of my exact model that needed a heating element. Wasn't 100% sure if the issue was the heating element or thermostat or ??? I ordered this kit b/c for a few $s I got the extra parts just in case. I replaced the heating element & it took ~1/2 hr start to finish & wasn't hard... I'd say it's 'medium' difficulty depending on your handyman ability. Some will find it very simple to do. My old heating element did indeed have a broken coil, so I felt pretty good about the diagnosis. After installing the new heating element the old dryer is working great again. We've had it fixed for ~a week & done ~10 loads & so far so good. Be sure to wear rubber gloves to keep skin oils off the coils. Be sure to thoroughly clean the inside of the dryer (esp. the tube that holds the heating element). All that dust in all those places is a serious fire hazard. Good luck. I'm thrilled I spent ~$35 & ~1/2 hr & have a good working dryer again... Would give 5 Stars, but longevity is yet to be seen...

title: Comes in handy if you have limited space. Very flexible, yet rolls up easily when needed. Perfect fit.
text:
This is an item I use every day in my kitchen. We have limited counter space, so there's no place to put a dish drying rack. We do have a dishwasher, but this is perfect for items I use regularly (like my tea mug) or quick wash items. Luckily, we have a dual tub sink so this has a permanent position over the tub on the right side.

The rack fits nicely over my sink and is very flexible. I love that you can easily squeeze plates and such in between the bars. They appear as if they're stretching out of shape but as soon as you remove the plate, they go right back to the way they were before - no shape lost.

If you ever do need to use the sink or the side that this is on, it rolls up very easily. I used to just place dishes in the sink to dry, but often they'd still be wet hours later because the water would gather underneath inside the sink. This allows items to drip dry so that isn't a problem. It's perfect for our household.

A free sample was provided for evaluation and review.

title: More convenient and easier than using the coffee maker. Easy to use and quick cleanup.
text:
I don't drink coffee every day - maybe 2-3 days out of the week. However, I'm so happy to have this on hand because one of the reasons I don't make coffee as regularly is because I don't feel like going through the trouble of pulling out the coffee maker or making 1/2 a pot (I never make a full pot).

This pour over coffee dripper allows me to make just one mug full and be done with it! No electricity needed and I don't have to mess up all the pieces involved with the coffee maker. It's super easy to use and easy to clean up.

The first time, I poured the water in too fast and it didn't work properly (my bad). Now, I know to slowly pour in the water a little at a time. It only takes a few minutes and then I have a nice cup of coffee that is pretty much brewed to perfection!

This is great for anyone who wants to speed up the coffee making process or if you want to make it on-the-go (of course, you will need some hot water in a thermos or something). It definitely prefer this to using the coffee maker.

A free sample was provided for evaluation and review.

title: Okay Value
text:
It says that it's a perfect fit, not really a tight fit, after the capsule is ejected, the so called perfect fit will fall off. As a matter of fact, you can still spin this piece of silicone after you apply it to the capsule. Definitely reusable, still produces the Crema, but you must you use a fine or espresso grind. You must use a Vertuo capsule, the instructions tell you to fill at 70%, this will produce a very weak cup of brew. Probably why most reviews for flavor are poor. To brew a true 7.77 oz of coffee, the original capsules are packed with 12.5 grams of fine grounded coffee beans. A 70% fill will result in using 8.75 oz, a single espresso capsule contains 7 grams of coffee and a double espresso capsule contains 10 grams of coffee. The only way you're going to get the flavor you are accustomed to, is to use the same amount, (weight wise) of grinds (each scoop is about 3 ounces) that the capsule originally came with. Keep in mind that each capsule also has a unique bar code on it. This bar code determines brew cycle time, water temperature, water pressure, and how much water to dispense.
So in a nut shell, have multiple capsules available to test with, make sure to use a fine grind, don't use an old capsule that has been laying around as mold has already been growing inside the capsule. Clean right after using. I will explore other options

title: Don't oversoap your clothes
text:
I have the washer and dryer. The washer is noisy; I have nothing else to compare to except my very old washer that filled to the brim with water (wasteful). I just close the laundry room door when I am washing. I use mostly the delicate cycles on clothes to avoid any serious wrinkling issues; works just fine for me. The towels get put on bulky setting and every once in a while I use the Allergens setting to really clean them.

The washer does require a monthly Affresh cleaning tablet. I would not miss this step because what I read is that odors build up in these HD machines. I also leave my lid open and the little detergent drawer open to air it and dry it out after each laundry day.

I only use liquid HD detergent; powder may not always dissolve. I also don't use much detergent, depending on the soil level. For our everyday clothes, less than half a cup is fine to avoid any excessive residual soap issues on the clothes after washing. I never use liquid softener; I think it traps and holds the dirt in the washer crevices and does not rinse off well.

title: UPDATED AGAIN: Just don't, until Samsung steps up their customer service, just don't
text:
09/29/2017 UPDATE
Finally got the top compartment fixed, problem with the sealed unit so fortunately still under warranty (5 years for sealed unit). The repair time was about 6 weeks for the January 2017 failure. On July 7, 2017 the top compartment again stopped cooling. It took two weeks to get a technician this time. It was the same tech as in January. He shook his head and said he was going to report it as defective. It took until September 15, T E N (10) weeks before Samsung finally issued a refund for the purchase price. Those 10 weeks were pure ridiculousness, and all without a refrigerator. Customer Service for defective units was only available M-F from 2PM-5PM, 3 hours, ET. It generally took 10-12 redials just to get in the queue, then another hour MINIMUM, on hold, to get to a live person. We had all of the paperwork turned in within two weeks of agreeing to a "buy out", but another 8 weeks for a refund. The only additional compensation was $200 for spoiled food. Nothing for the 10 weeks of almost daily grocery store trips, inability to keep/use leftovers, and "fast food". All of the people I've dealt with have been very nice, but that did little mitigate the total customer service failure on Samsung's part. Call after call, for updates, with typical responses of "the claim is being reviewed". They offered me a buyout so what's to review? More weeks of "well, everything is here, I'm not sure what the hold up is. I'll make sure you get a call". And you guessed it, no call. I really, really like the layout of this fridge. I have a ton of Samsung electronics in my home with no issues. I never could have imagined such a complete and total failure of an appliance from product to service. Until they get their act together, just don't. Attached are the photos I was required to provide as part of the process-label removed from interior, and cord cut.
UPDATE
We've had this refrigerator for a while now. About a month ago the top compartment stopped cooling. It still isn't fixed. There is an issue with the sealed unit which is under a five year warranty. Unfortunately, Samsung has been unable to locate a certified technician to fix it. So I currently have a $4000 cabinet. I loved this refrigerator but am sorely disappointed in Samsung customer service. Think twice before purchasing any Samsung product until they get their customer service back on track.

title: Easy to install
text:
If the start switch on your compactor is broken, and this is the correct part for your model, go for it. Very easy install on my Whirlpool GX900QPLB0

1. Unplug compactor, or turn off at breaker but make sure power is OFF
2. Open compactor drawer
3. Remove 2 screws under the control panel
4. Lift control panel up slightly, then off
5. Mark the cables so you know where they reattach on new switch, or do what I did and take a pic with your phone
6. Remove the cables from old switch
7. Attach to new switch
8. Slide control panel back into place
9. Replace two screws under control panel
10.Plug compactor in, or turn on breaker

That's it!

title: CUISINART LOVER FOR LIFE
text:
To say I'm pleased with this coffee maker is a understatement. I've owned several Cuisinart coffee makers in the past. Including the version that this one replaced. After 6 years of use, it was time for a replacement. Of course my search began and ended with Cuisinart!

Unlike many of the reviews posted. I am pleased with the changes I've found compared to the previous model. Noticeably the area where the Pod is inserted is now flat and much easier to wipe down. While the water reservoir no longer blinks to indicate low water. You'll find notification displayed on the screen indicating when the water is low. Minor tweaks that in my opinion makes this coffee maker a great choice.

Easily change from inserting a ready to use Pod with the included insert fitting easily by lining arrows up to brewing station. Should you prefer to use your own coffee grinds, simply remove the Pod insert and use the supplied coffee filter basket. Comparing to previous model, the filter is a bit larger/taller. Should you prefer a stronger cup of coffee allowing for more grinds. The exposed buttons are user friendly changing between default setting of 8 ounces to less or more depending on your brew. Easily program coffee maker to have your coffee ready when you are by setting the clock. With a default setting to auto shut off after 30 minutes should you forget. Use hot water button for hot tea or if you just need hot water for another use. Another great feature I've found is there is no lag in heating up to brew your coffee. Turn the machine on. Simply open the Filter/Pod insert area, close and hit the appropriate button. Freshly brewed coffee/cappuccino or hot tea within seconds

Overall I feel this in a excellent choice for all your coffee needs. The design is sleek and looks great on any counter top. I have found this to be very user friendly. As with any new appliance, I do recommend reading the enclosed User Manual. If you've owned a similar model previously. It's virtually the same operation. Set up is easy. Adding water to the reservoir is made simple by removing tank or my choice in using a larger measuring cup without moving the entire tank. Just remove lid and add water.

Included you'll find the coffee maker packaged well and shipped inside a sufficiently protected larger box. User manual. One carbon filter and a reusable coffee filter pod. You can easily find additional of each should you require replacements or wish to add additional reusable coffee filter inserts.

My vote is a solid YES! I'm a huge fan of Cuisinart. The brand hasn't let me down yet and because of that, my first and only choice is Cuisinart. I hope my review has been helpful. Please click below to let me know. Thanks for reading and Happy Shopping!!!

MissKelly.xo
