title: Great cooktop at a great price.
text:
I spent a lot of time shopping for an induction cooktop. Most were very expensive. Then we saw this cooktop at half the price. I thought it was one of the best looking with a pattern that hides smudges. After researching all of the specs, it seems that the only thing missing is the ability to bridge 2 burners to cook with a grill. A feature I did not need or want.
Installation was easy. I replaced a GE Profile cooktop in a granite countertop.
Cooking is quick and easy. The controls are intuitive. Very happy with this purchase. I definitely recommend this cooktop.

title: Melitta #4 Filters White 6 pack of 100
text: What I liked about the filters was the fact that they are not bleached filters.  I would get seriously sick.  The rest of my comments are what I have found using these for a real long time.  I have a subscribe and save using these.  I have never got more than the lowest discount.  It never increases with amount or time.  Out of all the years I have used these, the brown ones were awful stinky to me and gave the coffee a not so fresh taste.  I won't tell you what it reminded me of, but not good worse than cardboard.  The white has a Good Taste the Most Positive thing about them and that they are USA made.  This is the first year though that my filters rip through the bottom, someone sent in a photo of exactly what it looked like for me and this was enough times that I just started using two filters instead of one.  I don't get filters ripping, but only get half of what I pay for.  It is my choice though, and I pay it because it is worth a Great Coffee in the morning or anytime along with Demur Sugar.  I gave 3 Stars for half the amount.  I think that is fair.

title: Got the 3 Pack of 100 to use up
text: I think after these filters, I will use the white ones again instead.  There is nothing really wrong with these, they work fine and the quality seems good.  Coffee time is my favorite time and I love the smell of coffee and the taste I savor, but I can smell the filter.  Yes, it seems that way.  Why?  Don't know.  It smells like a paper bag to me.  Now how would you like to drink your coffee through a paper bag ?  Now you know.  I originally was afraid that would be the case, but decided to just see when you got more for the brown ones.  More yes, but no more period.  I love my coffee and this makes coffee not putrid, but not as satisfying.  I don't recommend these over the white ones.

title: Awesome Filter's
text: I was using Melitta filters from someone who took forever to deliver and the seams at times would let loose making grinds in my coffee.  So I switched to these to see if I would like them better.  Number one it supports US Workers, number 2 it is just totally a better filter, it doesn't bust and number 3 is the fact the filter is made of a different kind of fiber that is stronger, has not awkward taste or fibers in your coffee and is actually quicker dispensing it.  Too the point I had a coffee that was all over the counter first time.  Not use to the quickness and all I can say is it has to be from the material that it is made from, tasteless, stronger, made in the USA.  The price too is less than the Brand name Melitta even when made here in the USA where you usually pay a quality wage for a decent days work.  I'm totally happy.

title: These should be included with every espresso machine!
text:
One of the biggest problems with making my own espresso has always been cleaning up afterwards. Grounds always end up working their way inside the machine, and it takes tools to truly ensure it's all out. I'd been using the same machine since before Amazon was even around, but recently replaced it and decided to see what was new in accessories, too.

My new machine came with few extras, just a drip tray, couple different insert sizes for the handset, and a scoop/tamper. Before, I would've thought that's all you really needed. I was wrong.

When I first saw one of these filters, I knew I had to have one, and I was right. A carafe, espresso cups, a milk pitcher... all those things are nice, but unnecessary for making a superb latt√©. This filter not only keeps the machine far cleaner, but causes more evenly distributed waterflow throughout the grounds as well, ensuring a better brew, every time.

While I've always tried to ensure my grounds were evenly set before I tamp them, no amount of fuss with needles or other specialized tools made to separate coffee lovers from their money, can distribute those grounds in a way that totally prevents channels from forming. Those channels are visible evidence of uneven waterflow through the grounds, meaning not all grounds are getting the same flow. These filters are the only things I've seen that can fix that. They're not perfect, as they do have edges, but it's as vast an improvement over no-filter as espresso is over drip coffee (yes, that's my opinion - and I'm sticking to it!)

These filters should be as essential for making espresso as the handset, or at least the tamper. Such a serious improvement should always be incorporated into the basic process and included as essential equipment!

title: Coffee's Ready!
text:
This review based on a few days use but a fair amount of it.

First, these are much less bulky then the Keurig brand reusable pod. Secondly, there's plenty of mesh/screen to allow the liquid flow.
Third, they are dead easy to clean up. Just back flush.
Fourth, you can put up to two regular scoops of coffee in. I suggest tapping lightly but NOT tamping down.
Fifth, for the price point, this was a lot cheaper than the Keurig brand (which lasted us only about three months).

Six pods for a bit more than $10. That's cheaper than the Keurig as well.

We're pleased.

title: Love this little washer!
text:
I downsized and moved from a house into a 500-square foot studio apartment in the city back in February. One of the sacrifices I had to make -- or so I thought -- was private indoor laundry at home.

This little Haier changed that for me.

It is the smartest $200 or so that I have spent in a long time.

It is so cute and small, it fits right into my walk-in closet next to the bathroom. Works like a charm, I just move the washer out of the closet and a couple of feet into the bathroom, snap the hose onto the bathroom faucet and put the drain hose into the tub. I can do a whole week's worth of laundry in a couple of hours.

It holds roughly 1/3 to 1/2 of what most people would consider a normal load of clothes. In one wash load, I can do maybe 4 or 5 pairs of pants, or a full set of queen sheets (fitted bottom and flat top sheet); two large bath towels and two face towels.... you get the picture.

It is too small to wash my comfortor so I just do that once a month in the building laundromat downstairs.

I figure this machine has saved me at least $5/week in washing machine costs; probably more than that. So at this point the machine has already paid for itself.

I've never had any leaking problems except once when I experimented and washed a blanket that was too large for the machine. There was a small puddle on the bathroom floor afterwards; no big deal.

As long as you don't overstuff it, you shouldn't have any leaking issues.

It's also important to me that this machine is nice and new and CLEAN... I don't have to wonder who used the machine before me or what they put in it.

On a lighter note, this washing machine has also turned out to be something of a conversation piece. Whenever I have guests over and they see the washer next to the bathroom, they always comment on how cute and convenient it is.

I'm debating whether to get the Haier portable dryer; for now I use my shower curtain rod as a clothes line or I just do a bunch of loads of laundry, and take them downstairs to the laundromat dryer in one shot.

But it is so nice to have the option of doing all my laundry entirely in my apartment if I choose. Huge money saver and convenience. I highly recommend this machine.

The only (small) complaint I have about it is not really a complaint but more of a question. The drain hose and water line are very short. I wish they were a little longer so that I didn't have to move the washer into the bathroom (three feet away) to hook it up to the faucet.

I'm thinking of going to Home Depot and seeing if I can finding extensions for the water hose and the drain hose that would be long enough to reach into the bathroom.

If anyone has had any luck with that, please let me know.

title: So easy to use and clean
text:
I use it in a half gallon mason jar.
There is plenty of room in the filter to make your cold brew coffee as strong as you like.
Just use your coffee grounds in the amount that you would for any other pot of coffee, I believe the recommended use is 1 tablespoon per cup of water.
Anyway that's how I did it.
I filled the container by slowly pouring water into the basket and letting it drain through to the mason jar until I knew that the coffee grounds were good and wet.
Then I gently poured filtered water filling up my mason jar. I set it on the counter overnight and the next morning I took the stainless steel filter out, dumped the grounds out in the garden and then rinsed it off in the kitchen sink Easy Peezy.
I saw someone mention the residue in the bottom of the mason jar, that residue is full of all of the beneficial goodness in coffee (magnesium, potassium, and various phenolic compounds, or antioxidants) and it doesn't affect the taste or my enjoyment in the least. Actually I'm glad it's there.
The great thing about cold brew is if you make it a little too strong for your liking it still isn't bitter and you can easily add a little bit more filtered water to your finished coffee to tone it down a little bit.
I like it being kind of strong because then I can make a latte of 50% coffee and 50% almond milk froth it up and it is so good.
In the picture you'll see I used it to make bulletproof coffee and let me tell you it's the best.
Highly recommend it.

title: This worked out great!
text:
I got lucky! As it goes with anything I install for plumbing, it's understood I am going to make three trips to the Big Orange Box Store for piece parts.

This installed beautifully and without problem, like I had done this before. I had already replaced my plumbing under the sink during the kitchen remodel with a 1/4" shut off for our future GE refrigerator. With the use of a 5/8" paddle bit, I drilled holes out of view and through the rear of our cabinets and had a couple feet of slack to connect the 1/4" fitting at the fridge. I flushed the line out into a 5 gallon bucket before I hooked it up to the fridge. For the first time in 30+ years, we have a refrigerator that dispenses ice AND water! Woo-Hoo!

title: Lukewarm review, but I'll keep it.
text:
I like it.

This has probably been the best user reviewed as well as economical model on the market today, but I expected a better result. It runs better then a 1990's machine, but it's not the 4 towel drying monster that I've read... Two large towels will range in time between 1.5hrs to 2 "for me" in the North-East (70 degree day). Also, a regular full load of laundry will take 1.5 hours, where a 1/2 load will take 45mins. Living in 1 of the largest cities in the US (with 1930's wiring) the 110V / 1400W (translates to 12.72 amps) hasn't caused a fire in "my apartment." At the end of the day, I don't think that I can find a better product that will work with my electrical constraints, so although my expectations are tempered... I like this machine.

FYI:
I need my machine to be very portable, so I put it on a 11.5" x 18" mini-dolly. Although it barely fits, the smooth legs do slip off, so I needed to lock the dryer's mini legs in place. I did this by screwing down round mini tins to the dolly's corners, and wrapped velcro (2 sided, no tape) around the machine and dolly. I used the soft side of the velcro against the machine (prevents scratching), but I also used a little tape-down scratchy pieces on top of the machine pointing up. This way the velcro not-only-sticks-to-itself, but it also doesn't shift aroound on top of the machine.... Finally, I cut a piece of Yoga-mat a little larger then the dolly, and place it under the machine to prevent dryer movement during use...

title: meh.... ok for $13 but size seems off
text:
First, here are the OUTER diameter sizes of the drip pan set:

for the small 6" pan, the outer diameter is: 7 and 3/8 (not 7.5")

for the large 8" pan, the outer diameter is 9.25" (NOT 9.5" like it says in the Q and A section)

For me this was/is a problem, as MOST if not all pans with an 8" bowl have a 9.5" outer diameter, so my
heating element does not sit flush at all. As a matter of fact, a portion of it sits ABOVE the bowl and rests on
the outer lip which makes this unusable.

The smaller ones , the heating elements do go into the bowl but not flush either, its slightly off so the pans are
a bit lop sided but not as bad as the larger one that doesn't even sit in the bowl. So in these smaller ones, liquids
will bunch up more to one side, so its not even. Not acceptable either especially if what you are cooking, needs
to be in a flat level pan.

I've already opened up a return and I'm sending these back. What's annoying is that if you look at the questions people have asked about these, one of the answers there CLEARLY state these outer diameters are 7.5" and 9.5" which is NOT true, and those small amounts that these pans are off by, make a BIG difference!

title: Easy Way to Avoid an Opened Fridge
text: This is a nice and easy solution to prevent leaving your refrigerator or freezer opened accidentally. The package comes with two alarms with batteries already installed. You just have to attach the adhesives, pull out the plastic tabs on the batteries, and stick it to your fridge. When installing, make sure the gap between the two pieces are not too far apart or it will trigger a false alarm. Ours ended up sticking out a bit as you can see from our photos. The alarm itself is fairly loud, not mind numbingly loud, but loud enough for us to hear from two rooms away on a quiet day.
